We used a variety of computational methods to explore the selection pressures. A Maximum Likelihood (ML) method was used to examine selection pressures [ 31]. In the analysis, the non-synonymous to synonymous rate ratio ( ω = d
N

S ) was determined codon-by-codon using various models of codon substitution. These models differ in how ω ratios are allowed to vary along the sequence. Four models of codon substitution were conducted in the study: M1a ( ω < = 1; nearly neutral), M2a ( ω < = 1 and ω > 1; positive selection), M7 (beta; a discrete distribution with 10 site classes to model values of ω between 0 and 1) and M8 (beta and ω > 1). M1a is nested with M2a, and M7 is nested with M8. Models that are nested are compared statistically using a Likelihood Ratio Test (LRT). Positive selection can be inferred when a group of codons with a ω ratio > 1 is identified and the likelihood of the codon substitution model in question is significantly higher ( p < 0.05) than that of a nested model that does not take positive selection into account. Lastly, using Bayes Empirical Bayes (BEB) methods, posterior probabilities were calculated to identify sites under positive selection (posterior Bayesian probability ( Pp) > 95%). All the analyses were performed by using CODEML from the PAML v4.9 package [ 32].
